description: Characterized by deficits in general mental abilities.
Results in impairments of adaptive functioning.
Disorder with onset during the developmental period that includes both intellectual and adaptive functioning deficits in conceptual, social, and practical domains.
Deficits in intellectual functions such as reasoning, problem solving, planning, abstract thinking, judgment, academic learning, and learning from experience.

duration: lifelong
description: Deficit in intellectual and adaptive functioning established before age 18.
Delayed motor, language, and social milestones.

related_diagnoses.Autism Spectrum Disorder: Common comorbidity, can complicate assessment of intellectual functioning.
related_diagnoses.Depressive and Bipolar Disorders: Can occur throughout the range of severity of intellectual disability.

symptoms: Persistent difficulties in acquiring and using language
Deficits in comprehension or production of vocabulary
Difficulties following instructions of increasing length
Difficulties remembering new words and sentences
description: Deficits in language acquisition and use.
Substantially lower language abilities compared to peers.

related_diagnoses.Intellectual Disability (Intellectual De: Not attributed to, but may coexist

description: Persistent difficulty with speech sound production that interferes with speech intelligibility or prevents verbal communication of messages.
Difficulties are not attributable to congenital or acquired conditions.

related_diagnoses.Specific learning disorder: Poorer prognosis if associated with speech sound disorder
related_diagnoses.Developmental coordination disorder: May be impaired in terms of motor coordination
related_diagnoses.Autism spectrum disorder: Loss of speech and language in a child under 3 years may be a sign
related_diagnoses.Epilepsy: Can be associated with acquired aphasia or Landau-Kleffner syndrome
related_diagnoses.Intellectual disability: Often presents as language delay, but separate diagnosis given if language deficits exceed intellectual limitations
related_diagnoses.Down syndrome, 22q deletion, FoxP2 gene: Speech production problems may be differentially impaired in these genetic conditions

symptoms: Sound prolongations of consonants and vowels
Audible or silent blocking (filled or unfilled pauses in speech)
Circumlocutions (word substitutions to avoid problematic words)
Words produced with an excess of physical tension
description: Disturbance in the normal fluency and time patterning of speech.
Interference with academic or occupational achievement or social communication.
Persistent deficits in social communication and social interaction.
Restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, or activities.

related_diagnoses.Social (Pragmatic) Communication Disorde: May be diagnosed instead if symptoms don't fully meet criteria for ASD
related_diagnoses.Intellectual Disability (Intellectual De: Frequently co-occurs; social communication should be below that expected for general developmental level to diagnose both conditions.

symptoms: Severe deficits in verbal and nonverbal social communication skills
Very limited initiation of social interactions
Minimal response to social overtures from others
Other restricted/repetitive behaviors interfering with functioning
Great distress/difficulty changing focus or action
Noticeable impairments in social communication even with supports in place
Limited initiation of social interactions and reduced/abnormal responses to social overtures from others
Atypical or unsuccessful responses to social overtures of others
Significant interference caused by inflexibility of behavior in one or more contexts
Problems of organization and planning hampering independence
description: Persistent impairment in reciprocal social communication and social interaction.
Restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, or activities.

symptoms: Absent, reduced, or atypical social interest
Inappropriate approaches seeming aggressive or disruptive
Lack of shared social play and imagination
Insistence on playing by very fixed rules
Difficulty understanding appropriate behavior in different situations
Misunderstanding how language is used (e.g., irony)
Preference for solitary activities or interacting with people significantly younger or older
Desire to establish friendships without a complete idea of what they entail
Excessive adherence to routines and rigid patterns of behavior
Highly restricted, fixated interests with abnormal intensity or focus
Extreme reactions to sensory input (e.g., sounds, textures)
description: Social communication deficits judged against norms for age, gender, and culture.
Restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, or activities.

related_diagnoses.Intellectual Disability: May coexist with autism spectrum disorder.
related_diagnoses.Language Impairment: Commonly associated with autism spectrum disorder.

symptoms: Difficulties in early childhood and early school years
Developmental gains in later childhood in some areas
Behavioral deterioration during adolescence for a small proportion
Difficulties organizing practical demands without aid
Compensation strategies used to mask difficulties in public
Impairments causing current functioning issues in social, occupational, or other important areas
description: A neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by persistent deficits in social communication and interaction across multiple contexts.
Defined by the presence of restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, or activities.

related_diagnoses.Rett syndrome: May exhibit similar symptoms during regression phase but improves later.
related_diagnoses.Selective mutism: Early development not typically disturbed, appropriate communication in certain contexts.
related_diagnoses.Language disorders and social (pragmatic: Problems of communication and secondary social difficulties without abnormal nonverbal communication or restricted/repetitive patterns of behavior.
related_diagnoses.Intellectual disability (intellectual de: Differentiation can be challenging in young children. Appropriate if no significant discrepancy between social-communicative skills and other intellectual skills.

symptoms: Overly focused or easily distracted attention
description: Persistent pattern of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity interfering with functioning or development.
Difficulty sustaining attention, finishing tasks, staying organized.

related_diagnoses.autism spectrum disorder: may coexist, requiring dual diagnosis if criteria for both are met
related_diagnoses.other comorbid mental disorders: common, including anxiety disorders, depressive disorders, etc.

description: A persistent pattern of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity interfering with functioning or development.
Manifests as wandering off task, lacking persistence, disorganization, and impulsive behaviors.

related_diagnoses.antisocial personality disorder: increased likelihood for substance use disorders and incarceration
related_diagnoses.substance use disorders: elevated risk, especially when conduct disorder or antisocial personality disorder develops

description: a disorder characterized by persistent patterns of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity that impairs functioning or development

related_diagnoses.oppositional defiant disorder: may resist work or school tasks that require self-application due to negativity, hostility, and defiance
related_diagnoses.intermittent explosive disorder: high levels of impulsive behavior, but does not include serious aggression towards others nor inattention issues like ADHD
related_diagnoses.autism spectrum disorder: similar social dysfunction and peer rejection, but distinct in terms of social disengagement, isolation, and communication cues
related_diagnoses.reactive attachment disorder: shows social disinhibition but lacks the full ADHD symptom cluster and displays different features
related_diagnoses.anxiety disorders: shared symptoms of inattention, but differs in cause - ADHD due to attraction to external stimuli while anxiety due to worry and rumination
related_diagnoses.depressive disorders: presents with inability to concentrate, but only during a depressive episode
related_diagnoses.bipolar disorder: includes increased activity, poor concentration, and impulsivity episodically accompanied by elevated mood, grandiosity, etc.
related_diagnoses.disruptive mood dysregulation disorder: characterized by pervasive irritability and intolerance of frustration, but impulsiveness and disorganized attention are not essential features
related_diagnoses.substance use disorders: differentiation may be problematic if the first presentation of ADHD symptoms follows the onset of abuse or frequent use.

description: Difficulties learning and using academic skills.
Symptoms causing clinically significant distress or impairment.

related_diagnoses.Oppositional Defiant Disorder: Co-occurs in approximately half of children with the combined presentation and about a quarter with the predominantly inattentive presentation.
related_diagnoses.Conduct Disorder: Co-occurs in about a quarter of children or adolescents with the combined presentation.
related_diagnoses.Disruptive Mood Dysregulation Disorder: Most children and adolescents with symptoms meeting criteria for both ADHD and DMDD.
related_diagnoses.Anxiety Disorders: Occurs in a minority of individuals with ADHD but more often than in the general population.
related_diagnoses.Major Depressive Disorder: Occurs in a minority of individuals with ADHD but more often than in the general population.
related_diagnoses.Intermittent Explosive Disorder: Occurs in a minority of adults with ADHD, but at rates above population levels.
related_diagnoses.Substance Use Disorders: Present in only a minority of adults with ADHD.
related_diagnoses.Antisocial Personality Disorder: May co-occur with ADHD in adults.

symptoms: Avoidance of activities requiring academic skills
Interference with occupational performance or everyday activities requiring those skills
description: Neurodevelopmental disorder with a biological origin.
Disruption of the normal pattern of learning academic skills.

related_diagnoses.Global Developmental Delay: Not attributable to global developmental delay
related_diagnoses.Hearing or Vision Disorders: Not attributable to hearing or vision disorders
related_diagnoses.Neurological or Motor Disorders: Not attributable to neurological or motor disorders

symptoms: Trouble understanding the magnitude of numbers
Confusion between words that sound alike
Memory issues regarding dates, names, and phone numbers
Fear of reading aloud or refusal to read aloud
Difficulties making inferences from written text
Avoidance of activities demanding reading or arithmetic
description: A clinical diagnosis based on a synthesis of various factors including medical, developmental, educational, and family histories.
Lifelong condition characterized by variable course and clinical expression.

related_diagnoses.Autistic Spectrum Disorder: Cognitive deficits associated with specific learning disorder are found in this disorder too
related_diagnoses.Communication Disorders: Similar cognitive deficits are present in this disorder
related_diagnoses.Developmental Coordination Disorder: Similar cognitive deficits are present in this disorder too

symptoms: Problems making important inferences from numerical information
Avoidance of activities demanding reading or writing
Inability to master the basic sense of number
Lack of proficiency in word identification or spelling
Episodes of severe anxiety or anxiety disorders
description: Circumscribed learning difficulties that persist across the lifespan.
Marked problems with inattentive behavior predicting later difficulties in reading and mathematics.

related_diagnoses.ADHD: Co-occurrence is more frequent than expected by chance. Both diagnoses can be given if criteria for both are met.

symptoms: Slowness and inaccuracy of performance of motor skills
Difficulties in acquiring and executing coordinated motor skills
description: Substantially below average motor skills compared to one's age.
Significantly interferes with daily activities.

related_diagnoses.Autism Spectrum Disorder: Shared genetic effects suggested in severe cases.

symptoms: Repetitive, seemingly driven, and apparently purposeless motor behavior
Interference with social, academic, or other activities
description: Essential feature of repetitive, rhythmic, or apparently purposeless motor behavior
Behaviors may be rhythmical movements of the head, hands, or body without obvious adaptive function

related_diagnoses.Intellectual Disability (Intellectual De: Co-occurrence may increase risk of stereotypic movements and self-injury
related_diagnoses.Neurological Condition: Not attributed to physiological effects of substances or conditions
related_diagnoses.Other Neurodevelopmental or Mental Disor: Excluded as cause of stereotypic movements

duration: Typically begins within the first 3 years of life.
description: Purposeless, stereotypical movements or gestures

related_diagnoses.Neurogenetic Syndromes: May occur as a primary diagnosis or secondary to another disorder
related_diagnoses.Autism Spectrum Disorder: Stereotypic movements may be a presenting symptom
related_diagnoses.Tic Disorders: Distinguished by age at onset, consistency, and duration of movements
related_diagnoses.Obsessive-Compulsive and Related Disorde: Distinguished by the nature of repetitive behaviors and lack of obsessions
related_diagnoses.Other Neurological Conditions: Requires exclusion through neurological history and examination

symptoms: Sudden, rapid, recurrent, nonrhythmic motor movements or vocalizations
Involuntary suppression of tics for varying lengths of time
Simple motor tics (eye blinking, shoulder shrugging)
Simple vocal tics (throat clearing, sniffing, grunting)
Complex motor tics (combination of simple tics like simultaneous head turning and shoulder shrugging)
Palilalia (repeating one's own sounds or words)
Echolalia (repeating the last heard word or phrase)
Coprolalia (abrupt, sharp bark or grunt utterances without social interaction prosody)
duration: Persistent symptoms assured by 1-year minimum duration criterion.
description: Comprise four diagnostic categories: Tourette’s disorder, persistent (chronic) motor or vocal tic disorder, provisional tic disorder, and other specified and unspecified tic disorders.
Characterized by sudden, rapid, recurrent, nonrhythmic motor movements or vocalizations.

related_diagnoses.Major Depressive Disorder: More likely to develop in adolescents and adults
related_diagnoses.Substance Use Disorder: More likely to develop in adolescents and adults
related_diagnoses.Bipolar Disorder: More likely to develop in adolescents and adults

description: Involuntary, repetitive, patterned movements or vocalizations

related_diagnoses.Depression: More likely experienced by women with persistent tic disorders
related_diagnoses.substance use disorders: Can also occur alongside tic disorders

symptoms: Grossly Disorganized or Abnormal Motor Behavior
description: Fixed beliefs that cannot be changed based on evidence.
Perception-like experiences without external stimuli.

related_diagnoses.Schizotypal Personality Disorder: Within the schizophrenia spectrum, milder forms of cognitive and perceptual distortions.
related_diagnoses.Delusional Disorder: At least 1 month of delusions but no other psychotic symptoms.
related_diagnoses.Substance/Medication-Induced Psychotic D: Psychosis caused by drugs or toxins.
related_diagnoses.Psychotic Disorder Due To Another Medica: Psychosis directly resulting from another medical condition.
related_diagnoses.Catatonia Associated With Another Mental: Catatonia occurring alongside other mental disorders.

description: Presence of one or more delusions lasting for at least a month.
Hallucinations, if present, are not prominent and relate to the delusional theme.

related_diagnoses.schizophrenia spectrum disorders: considered part of the schizophrenia spectrum
related_diagnoses.personality disorders: specifically schizotypal personality disorder listed under both sections

symptoms: Cheating, spying, malicious maligned, harassment delusions
Somatic delusions involving bodily functions or sensations
Belief in emitting a foul odor
Ugly or misshapen body parts delusion
duration: At least 1 month
description: Presence of one or more non-bizarre delusions persisting for at least 1 month.
Impairments in psychosocial functioning may be more circumscribed compared to other psychotic disorders.

related_diagnoses.Schizophrenia: Not given if the individual has ever had a symptom presentation that met Criterion A for schizophrenia.
related_diagnoses.Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder: Diagnosis of Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder, with absent insight/delusional beliefs specifier, should be given instead if the individual is completely convinced about OCD beliefs.
related_diagnoses.Body Dysmorphic Disorder: Diagnosis of Body Dysmorphic Disorder, with absent insight/delusional beliefs specifier, should be given instead if the individual is completely convinced about body image concerns.

symptoms: sudden onset of at least one of the following positive psychotic symptoms:
grossly abnormal psychomotor behavior, including catatonia
rapid shifts from one intense affect to another
poor judgment, cognitive impairment, or acting on the basis of delusions
duration: lasts at least 1 day but less than 1 month
description: a disturbance involving sudden onset of psychotic symptoms lasting up to 1 month with eventual full return to premorbid functioning.
includes delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, or grossly abnormal psychomotor behavior.

related_diagnoses.schizophreniform disorder: if psychotic symptoms persist for at least 1 day
related_diagnoses.substance/medication-induced psychotic d: when caused by substances or medications
related_diagnoses.depressive and bipolar disorders with ps: ruled out based on timing and type of symptoms
related_diagnoses.other psychotic disorders: differentiated based on symptom duration and other presenting symptoms
related_diagnoses.personality disorders: brief periods of psychotic symptoms precipitated by stress may be seen but don't warrant a separate diagnosis unless persistent beyond 1 day.

duration.range: At least 1 month but less than 6 months

description: Identical characteristic symptoms to schizophrenia.
Duration distinguishes it from schizophrenia.

related_diagnoses.Brief psychotic disorder: Longer duration than brief psychotic disorder.

symptoms: Minor physical facial and limb anomalies
description: Psychosis emerging between late teens and mid-30s.
Positive symptoms often diminishing with age.

related_diagnoses.Depression: Can feature psychotic or catatonic elements.
related_diagnoses.Autism Spectrum Disorder: Shares symptoms like disorganized speech and behavior.

description: An uninterrupted period of illness during which there is a major mood episode (major depressive or manic) concurrent with Criterion A of schizophrenia.
Symptoms that meet criteria for a major mood episode are present for the majority of the total duration of the active and residual portions of the illness.

related_diagnoses.Schizophrenia: Concurrent with Criterion A of schizophrenia
related_diagnoses.Major depressive disorder: concurrent with Criterion A of schizophrenia
related_diagnoses.Obsessive-compulsive disorder: Elevated rates in individuals with schizophrenia
related_diagnoses.Panic disorder: Elevated rates in individuals with schizophrenia
related_diagnoses.Schizotypal or paranoid personality diso: May sometimes precede the onset of schizophrenia
related_diagnoses.Delirium or major or minor neurocognitiv: Psychotic symptoms temporally related to onset of cognitive changes
related_diagnoses.Substance/Medication-induced psychotic d: Chronological relationship of substance use to the onset and remission of psychosis in the absence of substance use

description: A mental health condition characterized by continuous signs of a psychotic disorder (such as delusions or hallucinations) along with a separate period of major depressive or manic episodes.

related_diagnoses.schizophrenia: may be distinguished by severity and persistence of negative symptoms
related_diagnoses.bipolar disorder: can differ in terms of predominant mood symptoms
related_diagnoses.major depressive disorder: can vary in presence and timing of mood episodes

description: A mental health condition characterized by a mix of psychotic and mood symptoms.
Prominent delusions and/or hallucinations for at least 2 weeks in the absence of a major mood episode.

related_diagnoses.Schizophrenia: Often difficult to differentiate from schizoaffective disorder based on symptom presentation.
related_diagnoses.Depressive and Bipolar Disorders with Ps: Can be distinguished from schizoaffective disorder by the fact that psychotic features primarily occur during mood episodes.
related_diagnoses.Psychosis Due to Another Medical Conditi: Needs to be ruled out due to potential overlap in symptoms.

duration: Can persist for weeks.
description: Prominent delusions and/or hallucinations caused by physiological effects of a substance/medication

related_diagnoses.Primary Psychotic Disorder: Distinguished by considering onset, course, and other factors.

duration: typically self-limited and resolves upon removal of the offending agent
description: Psychosis resulting from substance or medication use.
May involve hallucinations, delusions, or other perceptual disturbances.

related_diagnoses.Substance Intoxication or Substance With: Distinguishable by intact reality testing for perceived experiences attributed to substance use.
related_diagnoses.Delirium: Psychotic symptoms considered an associated feature if occurring during delirium.
related_diagnoses.Major or Mild Neurocognitive Disorder: Delusions diagnosed under this condition if no substance involvement.

diagnosis: Psychotic disorder due to another medical condition
description: Delusions or hallucinations attributed to a medical condition.
May vary in terms of onset, exacerbation, or remission linked to the underlying medical condition.

related_diagnoses.substance/medication-induced psychotic d: Considered when there is evidence of recent or prolonged substance use, withdrawal, or exposure to toxins.
related_diagnoses.delirium: Commonly involves hallucinations and delusions, but a separate diagnosis of psychotic disorder due to another medical condition isn't given if the disturbance occurs exclusively during delirium.
related_diagnoses.major or mild neurocognitive disorder: With behavioral disturbance if delusions occur in this context.

description: Marked psychomotor disturbance involving at least three of the 12 diagnostic features.
Can occur in various disorders including neurodevelopmental, psychotic, bipolar, depressive disorders, and other medical conditions.

related_diagnoses.Schizophrenia spectrum and other psychot: May be present in these disorders
related_diagnoses.Substance/medication-induced psychotic d: May be present in this disorder
related_diagnoses.Neuroleptic malignant syndrome: Consideration should be given to differential diagnosis
related_diagnoses.Medical conditions like infections, meta: Causes catatonia due to another medical condition

description: Category for presentations with catatonic symptoms causing distress or impairment, lacking clear underlying mental disorder or meeting full catatonia criteria.

related_diagnoses.Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychot: Predominate symptoms but don't meet full criteria for any specific disorder.
related_diagnoses.Bipolar and Related Disorders: Bridge between schizophrenia spectrum and depressive disorders; includes bipolar I, II, cyclothymic disorder, etc.

symptoms: More talkative than usual or pressure to keep talking
Flight of ideas or subjective experience that thoughts are racing
Excessive involvement in activities with high potential for painful consequences
description: Characterized by periods of elevated mood (mania) and depressed mood

symptoms: marked impairment in social or occupational functioning
require hospitalization to prevent harm to self or others
increased irritability, edginess, or agitation following antidepressant use
poor judgment, loss of insight, and hyperactivity
rapid shifts to anger or depression
hostile and physically threatening behavior towards others
sexual or social disinhibition in late mid-life or late-life
irritability associated with both major depressive disorder and bipolar disorder
description: A type of mood disorder characterized by extreme changes in mood, energy levels, activity levels, and the ability to carry out day-to-day tasks.
Marked by periods of abnormally elevated moods (mania) alternating with periods of depression.

related_diagnoses.major depressive disorder: may be accompanied by hypomanic or manic symptoms
related_diagnoses.generalized anxiety disorder, panic diso: need to be considered in the differential diagnosis as either the primary disorder or a comorbid disorder

description: Distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood.
Abnormally and persistently increased activity or energy.

related_diagnoses.Anxiety Disorders: May be confused with bipolar disorder
related_diagnoses.Personality Disorders: Substantial symptomatic overlap with bipolar disorders

symptoms: feelings of emptiness and loss (during grief)
positive emotions and humor (uncharacteristic of depression)
description: Recurring mood episodes consisting of one or more major depressive episodes and at least one hypomanic episode.
Hypomanic episodes lasting at least 4 days, causing no significant impairment.
A mood disorder characterized by alternating periods of depression and hypomania.
Hypomanic episodes define this disorder.

related_diagnoses.Major Depressive Disorder: May be misdiagnosed due to shared symptoms like depression.
related_diagnoses.Cyclothymic Disorder: Distinguished by the presence of one or more major depressive episodes.
related_diagnoses.Schizophrenia Spectrum & Psychotic Disor: Differentiated based on the absence of prominent mood symptoms and presence of psychosis.

duration: chronic, fluctuating mood disturbance involving numerous periods of hypomanic symptoms and periods of depressive symptoms
description: Essential feature is a chronic, fluctuating mood disturbance involving numerous periods of hypomanic symptoms and periods of depressive symptoms.
Hypomanic symptoms are of insufficient number, severity, pervasiveness, or duration to meet full criteria for a hypomanic episode.
Depressive symptoms are of insufficient number, severity, pervasiveness, or duration to meet full criteria for a major depressive episode.

related_diagnoses.major depressive disorder: if subsequent experience of a major depressive, manic, or hypomanic episode occurs
related_diagnoses.bipolar I disorder: if subsequent experience of a major depressive, manic, or hypomanic episode occurs
related_diagnoses.other specified or unspecified bipolar a: if subsequent experience of a major depressive, manic, or hypomanic episode occurs
related_diagnoses.schizoaffective disorder: not diagnosed if the pattern of mood swings is better explained by...
related_diagnoses.schizophrenia: not diagnosed if the pattern of mood swings is better explained by...
related_diagnoses.schizophreniform disorder: not diagnosed if the pattern of mood swings is better explained by...
related_diagnoses.delusional disorder: not diagnosed if the pattern of mood swings is better explained by...

description: Characterized by numerous periods of hypomanic symptoms and depressive symptoms over at least two years.
May involve genetic and physiological factors.

related_diagnoses.Bipolar and related disorder due to anot: Made when the mood disturbance is attributed to a specific medical condition.
related_diagnoses.Bipolar I disorder, bipolar II disorder: More common among first-degree biological relatives.
related_diagnoses.Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder: Commonly comorbid in child treatment settings.

description: Aprominent and persistent period of abnormally elevated, expansive, or irritable mood and abnormally increased activity or energy.
Essential features similar to mania, hypomania, or depression but caused by substance/medication use.

diagnosis: Bipolar and Related Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition
description: Presence of a prominent and persistent period of abnormally elevated, expansive, or irritable mood and abnormally increased activity or energy predominating in the clinical picture that is attributable to another medical condition.

related_diagnoses.Delirium: Differentiate symptoms of mania from excited or hypervigilant delirious symptoms.
related_diagnoses.Catatonia: Differentiate symptoms of mania from excited catatonic symptoms.
related_diagnoses.Acute anxiety: Differentiate symptoms of mania from agitation related to acute anxiety states.
related_diagnoses.Substance/Medication Induced Depressive: Important differential diagnostic observation - the other medical condition may be treated with medications that can induce depressive or manic symptoms.

description: One or more hypo-manic episodes...
Multiple episodes of hypomanic symptoms...

duration: null
description: Atypical features dominate during the majority of days of the current or most recent major depressive episode.
Mood reactivity - ability to brighten in response to positive events.
Significant weight gain or increased appetite.
Hypersomnia (extended sleep or daily naps totaling ≥10 hours)
Leaden paralysis (heavy, leaden feeling in arms or legs)
Long-standing pattern of interpersonal rejection sensitivity.

related_diagnoses.Seasonal Pattern: Regular temporal relationship between mood episodes and a particular time of year
related_diagnoses.Peripartum Onset: Onset of mood symptoms during pregnancy or within 4 weeks of delivery
related_diagnoses.Catatonia: Present during most of the episode
related_diagnoses.Psychotic Features: Delusions or hallucinations present at any time in the episode

description: Chronic, severe persistent irritability.
Frequent temper outbursts verbally and/or behaviorally.
Persistent irritable or angry mood between temper outbursts.

duration: Persistent over many months
description: A childhood condition characterized by severe, recurrent temper outbursts that are grossly out of proportion to the situation.
Symptoms occur persistently across different settings.

symptoms: persistent disruption in mood between outbursts
impairment in at least one setting (home, school, or among peers)
description: a childhood disorder characterized by frequent temper outbursts and persistently irritable or angry mood

related_diagnoses.intermittent explosive disorder: similar symptoms but different diagnostic criteria
related_diagnoses.bipolar disorder: do not diagnose if symptoms meet criteria for bipolar disorder

description: A period of at least 2 weeks with either depressed mood or loss of interest.

Presence of at least four additional symptoms including changes in appetite, sleep, and psychomotor activity, decreased energy, feelings of worthlessness or guilt, difficulties in thinking, concentration, or decision-making, and recurrent thoughts of death.

symptoms: impaired ability to think or concentrate
description: A mood disorder characterized by persistent feelings of sadness and loss of interest

related_diagnoses.Schizophrenia: Possible transition from major depressive disorder with psychotic features.

description: Depressed mood for most of the day, for more days than not, for at least 2 years.
Presence, while depressed, of two (or more) of the following...

related_diagnoses.schizophrenia: possible transition from major depressive disorder with psychotic features
related_diagnoses.attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder: distractibility and low frustration tolerance overlap
related_diagnoses.adjustment disorder with depressed mood: less severe than major depressive episode
related_diagnoses.other specified depressive disorder: for presentations of depressed mood without meeting full criteria for duration or severity
related_diagnoses.borderline personality disorder: markedly increases risk for future suicide attempts
related_diagnoses.anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, panic: frequent comorbidities with major depressive disorder

symptoms: Poor concentration or difficulty making decisions
duration: At least 2 years (1 year for children and adolescents)
description: Consolidation of DSM-IV defined chronic major depressive disorder and dysthymic disorder.
Essential feature is a depressed mood occurring for most of the day, for more days than not.

related_diagnoses.Schizoaffective Disorder: Not diagnosed if symptoms occur only during the course of the psychotic disorder.
related_diagnoses.Schizophrenia: Not diagnosed if symptoms occur only during the course of the psychotic disorder.
related_diagnoses.Delusional Disorder: Not diagnosed if symptoms occur only during the course of the psychotic disorder.

description: Chronic low-grade depression.
Symptoms often occur alongside psychotic disorders.

related_diagnoses.major depressive disorder: Higher risk for comorbidity compared to persistent depressive disorder
related_diagnoses.anxiety disorders: Higher risk for comorbidity compared to major depressive disorder
related_diagnoses.substance use disorders: Higher risk for comorbidity compared to major depressive disorder
related_diagnoses.DSM-IV Cluster B and C personality disor: Strongly associated with early-onset persistent depressive disorder
related_diagnoses.premenstrual dysphoric disorder: Not an exacerbation of symptoms according to diagnostic criteria

description: Affective and somatic symptoms that occur repeatedly during the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle.
Markedly impairs social or occupational functioning.

related_diagnoses.premenstrual syndrome: less severe, requires fewer symptoms, no stipulation of affective symptoms
related_diagnoses.bipolar disorder, major depressive disor: overlap in symptoms, require charting to differentiate
related_diagnoses.substance/medication-induced depressive: symptoms caused by hormonal treatments or substances/medications

duration: Symptoms typically remit within days to several weeks after discontinuation of substance.
description: Depressive symptoms associated with substance use or withdrawal.

related_diagnoses.Comorbid Substance Use Disorder: Often present when depressive symptoms arise due to substance use.
related_diagnoses.Primary Depressive Disorder: Must be ruled out if depressive symptoms persist beyond expected withdrawal period.

symptoms: thoughts of death and suicide attempts
description: Mood disturbance severe enough to require independent clinical attention.
Caused by substances or medications.

related_diagnoses.Major Depressive Disorder: Can coexist with substance/medication-induced depressive disorder.
related_diagnoses.Cocaine Withdrawal: May cause dysphoria, but substance/medication-induced depressive disorder requires more intense or prolonged symptoms.
related_diagnoses.Other Specified Depressive Disorder/Unsp: When insufficient evidence exists to link depressive symptoms to substances, another medical condition, or being primary.

diagnosis: Depressive Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition
description: A prominent and persistent period of depressed mood or markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities.
Thought to be related to the direct physiological effects of another medical condition.

related_diagnoses.adjustment disorder: may bring on either an adjustment disorder or an episode of major depression
related_diagnoses.medication-induced depressive disorder: Some medical conditions are treated with medications that can induce depressive or manic symptoms.

description: Presents with symptoms characteristic of a depressive disorder causing clinically significant distress or impairment.
Does not meet full criteria for any specific depressive disorder.

related_diagnoses.Recurrent Brief Depression: Concurrent presence of depressed mood and at least four other symptoms of depression for 2-13 days at least once per month for at least 12 consecutive months.
related_diagnoses.Short-Duration Depressive Episode: Depressed affect and at least four of the other eight symptoms of a major depressive episode associated with clinically significant distress or impairment that persists for more than 4 days, but less than 14 days.
related_diagnoses.Depressive Episode with Insufficient Sym: Depressed affect and at least one of the other eight symptoms of a major depressive episode associated with clinically significant distress or impairment that persist for at least 2 weeks.

symptoms: Significant weight gain or increase in appetite
Long-standing pattern of interpersonal rejection sensitivity
description: Characterized by persistent low mood, loss of interest or pleasure, and various physical and emotional symptoms.
Includes subtypes like 'atypical depression'
Seasonal patterns may exist

related_diagnoses.Bipolar II Disorder: More likely to exhibit seasonal patterns compared to Bipolar I Disorder
related_diagnoses.Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychot: Catatonic features can be associated with both conditions.

symptoms: fear of separation from attachment figures
persistent worry about harm to attachment figures
reluctance to leave home or go to school
physical symptoms like headaches, stomachaches, nausea, vomiting
duration: Typically lasting 6 months or more in adults, 4 weeks in children and adolescents.
description: Emotional response to perceived imminent threat
Anticipation of future threat
Persistent failure to speak in specific social situations despite speaking in others.
Typically manifests before age 5.

related_diagnoses.Social Anxiety Disorder: Most commonly co-occurs with selective mutism.
related_diagnoses.Separation Anxiety Disorder: May also coexist with selective mutism.
related_diagnoses.Specific Phobia: Can share similar characteristics like avoidance and fear disproportionate to threat.

description: Excessive fears in young children are usually transitory and mildly impairing.
Fear and anxiety regarding specific objects or situations.

related_diagnoses.Agoraphobia: May resemble situational specific phobia based on overlapping feared situations.
related_diagnoses.Social anxiety disorder: Should be diagnosed instead if the situations are feared because of negative evaluation.
related_diagnoses.Separation anxiety disorder: Should be diagnosed instead if the situations are feared because of separation from a primary caregiver or attachment figure.
related_diagnoses.Panic disorder: Considered if the individual also experiences panic attacks unrelated to the specific phobia object or situation.

symptoms: Marked fear or anxiety about social situations
Fear of acting in a way that will be negatively evaluated
Avoidance of social situations or enduring them with intense fear or anxiety
Anxiety out of proportion to the actual threat posed by the social situation
Clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning
duration: Typically lasting for 6 months or more
description: Essential feature: Marked, or intense, fear or anxiety of social situations

related_diagnoses.Body Dysmorphic Disorder: Can share similar features but distinct diagnoses
related_diagnoses.Autism Spectrum Disorder: Symptoms should not be attributed to these disorders

description: Fear of negative evaluation in social situations.
Avoidance of social interactions.

related_diagnoses.Agoraphobia: Fears and avoids social situations due to potential incapacitation or lack of help
related_diagnoses.Panic Disorder: Focus on fear of panic attacks instead of negative evaluation
related_diagnoses.Generalized Anxiety Disorder: Worry about ongoing relationships rather than social performance
related_diagnoses.Separation Anxiety Disorder: Concerns about being separated from attachment figures
related_diagnoses.Specific Phobias: Fear of embarrassment or humiliation in specific contexts
related_diagnoses.Selective Mutism: Failure to speak due to fear of negative evaluation in speaking situations
related_diagnoses.Major Depressive Disorder: Feelings of worthlessness leading to social anxiety
related_diagnoses.Body Dysmorphic Disorder: Preoccupation with perceived physical flaws causing social anxiety and avoidance

symptoms: sensations of shortness of breath or smothering
fear of losing control or 'going crazy'
description: Recurrent unexpected panic attacks

related_diagnoses.avoidant personality disorder: often comorbid with generalized form of social anxiety disorder

symptoms: worry about panic attacks or their consequences
embarrassment or fear of being judged negatively by others due to visible panic symptoms
concerns about going crazy or losing control
constant or intermittent feelings of anxiety related to health and mental health concerns
anticipating a catastrophic outcome from a mild physical symptom or medication side effect
extreme intolerance of medication side effects
pervasive concerns about abilities to complete daily tasks or withstand daily stressors
excessive use of drugs to control panic attacks
severe restrictions on food intake or avoidance of specific foods or medications due to concerns about physical symptoms that provoke panic attacks
description: A psychological disorder characterized by recurrent unexpected panic attacks
A psychological condition marked by sudden episodes of intense fear that reach a peak within minutes.

related_diagnoses.Major Depressive Disorder: Frequently comorbid, with varying order of onset.
related_diagnoses.Bipolar Disorder: Less common but still possible comorbidity.
related_diagnoses.Specific Phobia: May coexist, though panic attacks here are usually expected.
related_diagnoses.Generalized Anxiety Disorder: Coexistence is possible, again with expected panic attacks.

symptoms: Sensations of shortness of breath or smothering
Feeling dizzy, unsteady, light-headed, or faint
Fear of losing control or 'going crazy'
description: Abrupt surge of intense fear or intense discomfort reaching a peak within minutes

related_diagnoses.Substance-related disorder: Attempted self-treatment with alcohol or medication.

symptoms: abrupt surge of intense fear or discomfort
description: Abrupt surges of intense fear or discomfort

related_diagnoses.Agoraphobia: Fear or avoidance of situations where escape might be difficult or help unavailable.
related_diagnoses.Anxiety Disorders: Increased likelihood of comorbid mental disorders.
related_diagnoses.Depressive Disorders: Increased likelihood of comorbid mental disorders.

symptoms: fear or anxiety in response to agoraphobic situations
intense fear or anxiety upon encountering agoraphobic situations
fear disproportionate to the actual danger posed by the agoraphobic situations
duration: Typically lasting for 6 months or more
description: A mental health condition marked by fear or anxiety about being in places or situations where escape might be difficult or help unavailable.
This fear leads to active avoidance of those situations.

related_diagnoses.Panic Disorder: Often precedes or coexists with agoraphobia
related_diagnoses.Other Anxiety Disorders: May complicate the course of agoraphobia
related_diagnoses.Depressive Disorders: Commonly complicates the course of agoraphobia
related_diagnoses.Personality Disorders: Can complicate the course of agoraphobia
related_diagnoses.Specific Phobia, Situational Type: Differentiable based on fear focus and extent of avoidance

description: Fear or avoidance of situations where escape might be difficult or help unavailable during a panic attack.
Shared characteristics and criteria with specific phobias, especially situational type.

related_diagnoses.separation anxiety disorder: Differentiated by focusing on detachment from significant others and home environment instead of panic-like symptoms.
related_diagnoses.specific phobias: Shares symptoms but differs in requiring fears from two or more agoraphobic situations.
related_diagnoses.panic disorder: Differentiates through presence of panic attacks leading to avoidance of two or more agoraphobic situations.
related_diagnoses.social anxiety disorder: Focuses on fear of negative evaluation rather than panic-like symptoms.
related_diagnoses.acute stress disorder / PTSD: Distinguishes by restricting fear to reminders of traumatic events without extending to two or more agoraphobic situations.
related_diagnoses.major depressive disorder: Avoidance unrelated to fears of panic-like or other incapacitating or embarrassing symptoms.

symptoms: concern about school performance or competence
description: A persistent and excessive worry about everyday things.
Symptoms include muscle tension, tremors, and feelings of shakiness.

related_diagnoses.Separation Anxiety Disorder: Often accompanied by worries that may mimic those described in GAD.
related_diagnoses.Social Anxiety Disorder (Social Phobia): May be concerned about school performance because of fear of humiliation.
related_diagnoses.Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder: Worries may resemble those in GAD but are distinct due to intrusive and unwanted thoughts.

description: Excessive worry about future problems.
Excessiveness of worry about future events

related_diagnoses.obsessive-compulsive disorder: distinguished by different types of worries
related_diagnoses.posttraumatic stress disorder: anxiety is invariably present, not diagnosed separately if better explained by PTSD
related_diagnoses.adjustment disorder: residual category, anxiety responds to identifiable stressors within 3 months and doesn't persist beyond 6 months after stressor ends
related_diagnoses.depressive, bipolar, and psychotic disor: common associated feature, not diagnosed separately if only during these conditions
related_diagnoses.substance/medication-induced anxiety dis: caused by substance intoxication or withdrawal or medication exposure

duration: Usually improves or remits within days to several weeks to a month.
description: Prominent symptoms of panic or anxiety judged to be due to the effects of a substance.

related_diagnoses.Primary Anxiety Disorder: Distinguished based on onset, course, and other factors regarding substances/medications
related_diagnoses.Delirium: Symptoms are considered an associated feature of delirium
related_diagnoses.Anxiety Disorder Due to Another Medical: Diagnosed if panic or anxiety symptoms are attributed to another medical condition

diagnosis: Anxiety Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition
description: Clinically significant anxiety judged to be best explained as a physiological effect of another medical condition.
Prominent physical component to the anxiety.

related_diagnoses.Adjustment Disorder: Comorbid, but differs in that the stressor is specifically the medical condition in Adjustment Disorder vs. the anxiety being physiologically linked to the medical condition here.

description: characterized by worry about illness, concern about pain, and bodily preoccupations

related_diagnoses.adjustment disorders: warranted when individuals experience a maladaptive response to the stress of having another medical condition
related_diagnoses.anxiety disorder due to another medical: should be distinguished from illness anxiety disorder
related_diagnoses.schizophrenia, anorexia nervosa: may be an associated feature of another mental disorder

symptoms: Recurrent and persistent thoughts, urges, or images
description: Persistent difficulty discarding or parting with possessions
Excessive collecting, buying, or stealing of unnecessary items

related_diagnoses.trichotillomania (hair-pulling disorder): characterized by recurrent pulling out of one's hair
related_diagnoses.excoriation (skin-picking) disorder: characterized by recurrent picking of one's skin
related_diagnoses.substance /medication-induced obsessive-: due to substance intoxication or withdrawal or to a medication
related_diagnoses.obsessive-compulsive and related disorde: direct pathophysiological consequence of a medical disorder
related_diagnoses.body-focused repetitive behavior disorde: example of other specified obsessive-compulsive and related disorder

description: presence of obsessions and compulsions
intrusive and unwanted thoughts, images, or urges
marked distress or anxiety caused by obsessions
attempts to suppress or neutralize obsessions through compulsions

related_diagnoses.Tic disorders: common in males with childhood onset of OCD

symptoms: Forbidden thoughts and symmetry dimension symptoms
Aggressive obsessions interfering with mother-infant relationship
Contamination concerns avoiding doctors' offices and hospitals
Skin lesions due to excessive washing
Struggling to complete school or work projects due to symmetry concerns
Avoiding relationships out of fear of contamination
Time spent obsessing and doing compulsions
Avoidance of situations triggering obsessions or compulsions
description: Intrusive thoughts, images, or urges causing distress.
Behaviors or mental acts performed to neutralize these intrusions.

related_diagnoses.Tic Disorder: Co-occurrence especially in male patients with early onset.
related_diagnoses.Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder: Triad with OCD and Tic Disorder possible in children.
related_diagnoses.Anxiety Disorders: Recurrent thoughts, avoidant behaviors, and reassurance seeking overlap.
related_diagnoses.Generalized Anxiety Disorder: Worries about real-life concerns differentiate from OCD obsessions.
related_diagnoses.Specific Phobia: Fear reactions to specific objects or situations less circumscribed than OCD.
related_diagnoses.Social Anxiety Disorder (Social Phobia): Limited fear objects to social interactions differentiates from OCD.
related_diagnoses.Major Depressive Disorder: Mood congruent ruminations differentiate from OCD obsessions.
related_diagnoses.Body Dysmorphic Disorder: Obsessions and compulsions limited to physical appearance.
related_diagnoses.Trichotillomania (Hair-Pulling Disorder): Compulsive behavior limited to hair pulling without obsessions.
related_diagnoses.Hoarding Disorder: Difficulty discarding possessions, marked distress associated with discarding items.
related_diagnoses.Anorexia Nervosa: Obsessions and compulsions not limited to weight and food.
related_diagnoses.Paraphilias, Gambling Disorder, Substanc: Pleasure derived from activities differentiating from OCD compulsions.

symptoms: Preoccupation with perceived defects or flaws in physical appearance
Performing repetitive behaviors or mental acts in response to appearance concerns
Clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning
description: Perceived defects or flaws in physical appearance that are not observable or appear slight to others.
Intrusive, unwanted, time-consuming preoccupations.

related_diagnoses.Eating disorders: Not better explained by concerns with body fat or weight.
related_diagnoses.Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD): Elevated prevalence of body dysmorphic disorder in first-degree relatives of OCD patients.

description: Excessive appearance-related preoccupations and repetitive behaviors.
Impaired psychosocial functioning.

duration: chronic
description: Persistent difficulty discarding or parting with possessions.
This difficulty is due to a perceived need to save the items and to distress associated with discarding them.
Cluttering of active living areas resulting in substantial impairment.

related_diagnoses.Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD): Shares symptoms - fears of losing important information, perfectionism, avoidance, etc.

description: Difficulty discarding possessions regardless of their actual value.
Excessive accumulation of belongings leading to clutter that interferes with daily activities.

related_diagnoses.Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder: May coexist, especially when hoarding is linked to OCD-like obsessions or compulsions.
related_diagnoses.Mood or Anxiety Disorders: Approximately 75% of individuals with hoarding disorder have a comorbid mood or anxiety disorder, including Major Depressive Disorder, Social Anxiety Disorder, and Generalized Anxiety Disorder.

symptoms: Searching for specific texture or color of hair
Trying to pull out hair in a specific way
Visually examining, tactilely manipulating, or orally manipulating pulled hair
Emotional states preceding or accompanying hair pulling (anxiety, boredom)
Increasing sense of tension leading up to hair pulling
description: Chronic hair-pulling disorder
Characterized by repeated urge to pull out one's own hair

related_diagnoses.Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder: More common in individuals with OCD and their first-degree relatives
related_diagnoses.Body Dysmorphic Disorder: Not diagnosed if removing hair for perceived defects or flaws in appearance
related_diagnoses.Excoriation (Skin-Picking) Disorder: Majority of individuals with trichotillomania also have excoriation disorder

symptoms: Picking at healthy skin, minor skin irregularities, lesions like pimples or calluses, or scabs from previous picking
Using fingernails, tweezers, pins, or other objects for picking
Skin rubbing, squeezing, lancing, and biting
Spending significant time on picking behavior (sometimes several hours per day)
Attempting to conceal or camouflage skin lesions
Experiencing negative affects like loss of control, embarrassment, and shame
Avoiding social situations due to impairment in functioning
duration: Chronic with waxing and waning if untreated
description: Essential feature is recurrent picking at one's own skin leading to skin lesions.
Behavior may endure for months or years.

related_diagnoses.Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder: More common in individuals with OCD and their first-degree family members
related_diagnoses.Trichotillomania (Hair-Pulling Disorder): Often accompanied by other mental disorders including...
related_diagnoses.Body Dysmorphic Disorder: (Skin picking may occur...) in individuals with...appearance concerns; however, excoriation disorder should not be diagnosed.

description: Prominent symptoms of an obsessive-compulsive and related disorder attributed to the effects of a substance.
Symptoms developing during or soon after substance intoxication or withdrawal or after exposure to a medication.

related_diagnoses.Comorbid Substance Use Disorder: Mild, Moderate, Severe - depending on the context specified in coding notes.

description: Symptoms caused by substance intoxication.
May occur with stimulants like cocaine or heavy metals.

related_diagnoses.primary obsessive-compulsive and related: Distinguished by onset, course, and other factors unrelated to substances/medications.
related_diagnoses.delirium: Not diagnosed separately if symptoms exclusive to delirium.

symptoms: sudden intense anxiety regarding genital retraction
description: a group of disorders characterized by intrusive thoughts, impulses, images, or urges (obsessions) and repetitive behaviors or mental acts (compulsions)
combination of motor and nonmotor features including obsessions, compulsions, attention deficit, emotional lability
sudden onset of obsessions, compulsions, and/or tics accompanied by various acute neuropsychiatric symptoms after Group A streptococcal infection
preoccupation with having or acquiring a serious illness even when medically reassured otherwise
excessive fear of having a bodily deformity or offensive body odor
sudden and intense anxiety that the penis (or female genitalia) will recede into the body potentially leading to death

related_diagnoses.rheumatic fever: involves cardiac inflammation caused by Group A streptococcus bacteria, often preceding Sydenham's chorea
related_diagnoses.Sydenham's chorea: neurological manifestation of rheumatic fever, sharing motor and nonmotor features with OCD
related_diagnoses.PANDAS (pediatric autoimmune neuropsychi: post-infectious autoimmune disorder featuring abrupt onset of OCD-like symptoms after strep throat or skin infection
related_diagnoses.substance/medication-induced obsessive-c: caused by recent or prolonged substance use, withdrawal, or exposure to toxins resulting in OCD-like symptoms
related_diagnoses.delirium: OCD symptoms occurring solely during delirium warrant exclusion of independent OCD diagnosis unless coexisting dementia also presents with OCD symptoms
related_diagnoses.major neurocognitive disorder (dementia): if OCD symptoms arise physiologically from the same pathology causing dementia and constitute a prominent aspect of the clinical presentation, then both diagnoses apply simultaneously
related_diagnoses.schizophrenia: associated feature of OCD symptoms in schizophrenia patients
related_diagnoses.anorexia nervosa: associated feature of OCD symptoms in anorexia nervosa patients
related_diagnoses.taijin kyofusho variants like shubo-kyof: cultural concepts of distress involving extreme social anxiety over perceived bodily deformities or odors respectively akin to OCD symptomatology in Western contexts

description: Predominant symptoms characteristic of an obsessive-compulsive and related disorder causing clinically significant distress or impairment.
Insufficient information to diagnose a specific obsessive-compulsive and related disorder.

related_diagnoses.Trauma- and Stressor-Related Disorders: Close relationship; shares symptoms like anxiety, fear, depression, aggression, dissociation after exposure to trauma or stress.
related_diagnoses.Reactive Attachment Disorder: Shared etiology - social neglect; Reactive Attachment Disorder expresses as internalizing disorder with depressive symptoms and withdrawn behavior whereas Disinhibited Social Engagement Disorder shows disinhibition and externalizing behavior.

description: Profound reduction in positive affect.
Emotion regulation difficulties.
Lack of preferred attachment.

related_diagnoses.Autism Spectrum Disorder: Can share aberrant social behaviors, but differ in response to neglect and presence of restricted interests or ritualized behaviors.
related_diagnoses.Intellectual Disability (Intellectual De: May coexist due to common causes like neglect, but differs in social and emotional skills and absence of reduced positive affect.
related_diagnoses.Depressive Disorders: May coexist due to similar negative affective states, but differs in seeking and responding to comforting efforts by caregivers.

duration: more than 1 month
description: Exposure to actual or threatened death, serious injury, or sexual violence.
Presence of one (or more) of the following intrusion symptoms...
Persistent avoidance of stimuli associated with the traumatic event(s)...
Negative alterations in cognitions and mood associated with the traumatic event(s)...
Marked alterations in arousal and reactivity associated with the traumatic event(s)...

related_diagnoses.Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder: Differentiate between the two disorders based on lack of attention or hyperactivity issues.

symptoms: Recurrent, involuntary, and intrusive distressing memories of the traumatic event(s)
Distressing dreams in which the content and/or affect of the dream are related to the traumatic event(s)
Intense or prolonged psychological distress at exposure to internal or external cues symbolizing aspects of the traumatic event(s)
Marked physiological reactions to reminders of the traumatic event(s)
Avoidance of activities, places, or physical reminders that arouse recollections of the traumatic event(s)
Avoidance of people, conversations, or interpersonal situations that arouse recollections of the traumatic event(s)
Substantially increased frequency of negative emotional states
Persistent reduction in expression of positive emotions
duration: more than 1 month
description: Development of characteristic symptoms following exposure to one or more traumatic events
